author: pcgeek86
body:
PowerShell Core Edition doesn't have a `Set-Clipboard` command. I've tried using `pbcopy` on Mac OS X, but it doesn't seem to work well with certain UTF-8 characters, like emojis. For example, using my Emojis PowerShell module, on the PowerShell Gallery, the `pbcopy` command pastes an emoji into my web browser as a question mark.

Having a high-quality `Set-Clipboard` command would be convenient from a first-class PowerShell perspective, and resolving bugs similar to those with `pbcopy`.

Cheers,
Trevor Sullivan

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: pbcopy/pbpaste should work. @pcgeek86 Have you investigated to see if this is an encoding problem? It would be nice if Out-Clipboard could just be an alias to pbcopy.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
It is indeed an encoding issue: because `$OutputEncoding` defaults to ASCII, any non-ASCII chars. are converted to _literal_ `?` chars:

     > 'ö' | pbcopy; pbpaste | od -tx1
     0000000    3f  0a                                                        
     0000002

`3f` is literal `?` (and `0a` is `\n`).

If you set `$OutputEncoding` to BOM-less UTF-8, it works:

     > & { $OutputEncoding = [System.Text.Utf8Encoding]::New(); 'ö' | pbcopy; pbpaste | od -tx1 }
     0000000    c3  b6  0a                                                    
     0000003

`c3 b6` is the UTF-8 encoding of `ö`, proving that the value was copied correctly.
